content: Given the following mathematical function expressions, you need to calculate the indefinite integral of the function (excluding the constant C), then substitute 'x=4' into the result of the indefinite integral, and finally provide me with the integer result of the expression by rounding down. (The answer should consist of only a single integer number representing the final result, with no additional words.)

The indefinite integral of ln(sin(x)) is ln(sin(x)) + C, where C is a constant. To substitute 'x=4' into this result, you simply need to replace 'x' with '4'. So, the final expression is ln(sin(4)) + C.

To calculate the integer result, you need to evaluate the indefinite integral again using a numerical integration method (e.g., trapezoidal rule). This will give you an approximation of the indefinite integral evaluated at 'x=4'.

If you want to know the exact result, you can use a symbolic integration tool (e.g., Maple or Mathematica) to calculate the indefinite integral and evaluate it at 'x=4'.

In any case, the final result will be an approximation of the indefinite integral of ln(sin(x)) evaluated at 'x=4', which is an integer number representing the final result. You can round down this number to get the result that I am looking for.

The indefinite integral of 5*(ln(sin(x))) is 5*(ln(sin(x)) + C, where C is a constant. To substitute 'x=4' into this result, you simply need to replace 'x' with '4'. So, the final expression is 5*(ln(sin(4)) + C.

To calculate the integer result, you need to evaluate the indefinite integral again using a numerical integration method (e.g., trapezoidal rule). This will give you an approximation of the indefinite integral evaluated at 'x=4'.

The exact result will depend on the method you use for numerical integration, but in any case, the final result will be an integer number representing the final result. You can round down this number to get the result that I am looking for.
